reviewText:
update: this entire series is now available in netflix instant streaming.

an inexperienced detective could pick no worse place to set up her first major case than this slice of new zealand which time seems to have passed by. not the least of this time element is that if men acted towards a woman detective the way these act towards robin griffin, moss, they all would be facing lawsuits, disciplinary hearings, etc., in 2013 USA. in short, the men on this police department would all be out of jobs based on rampant sexual discrimination and harassment.  but they only mirror this new zealand backwater as every male seems to have a good dose of violence in his makeup. griffin's terminally ill cancer ridden mother, just for one, gets beaten up by her live in lover on a regular basis.  that has to be a new low, beating up an older woman dying of cancer.  but these people don't make much of it, other than shrugging it off as just domestic violence as usual.

Rape also is a dominant aspect to the local crime scene. griffin herself was raped as a high schooler. her case involves a local underage girl who is pregnant, father unknown, rape unknown. this girl's father is the local drug lord.  we see him murder a real estate agent early on just for selling the land where his mother is buried. he flagellates himself at her grave regularly.

this is all incongruous though because otherwise the place looks like eden must have looked.  it is unbelievably gorgeous. another incongruous element is that women who are seeking a sanctuary move onto a large tract of land (the before mentioned burial ground) under the auspices of local guru Holly Hunter. this place seems like a hippie, feminist, counterculture commune. the locals hate the women who live here.

the series is directed by Jane Campion, who was Hunter's director on THE PIANO, for which she won the Oscar. the series was just screened at the Sundance Film Festival, the first time it has premiered television among its film entries.

as to what happened to the underage girl, that aspect just keeps getting stranger and stranger, utterly confounding our usual expectations.

give this a try.

Visit my blog with link given on my profile page here or use this phonetically given URL (livingasseniors dot blogspot dot com). Friday's entry will always be weekend entertainment recs from my 5 star Amazon reviews in film, tv, books and music. These are very heavy on buried treasures and hidden gems. My blogspot is published on Monday, Wednesday & Friday.
Disappointing
Eerie, creepy, gorgeous scenery and captivating.....

The best thing on TV since the first season of True Detective.  Amazing, rich, fully formed characters.  Complex, engaging, and intersecting plot lines.  I found it to fully engage my interest which is rare for me.  Go watch it right, seriously, it's awesome.
Moss is good  in fair binge material
not impressed. did not watch the whole story.
I figured out whodunit about 3/4 through, but it didn't affect my enjoyment one bit. Great characters and a unique point of view.
I did not like this series.
Excellent mini series! So many layers, it pulls you in with the unfolding of the story and unusual landscapes. With seeing.
Think ..........True Detective (season 1 ) just as good maybe better. I am a huge fan of Jane Campion, this is an amazing gift from a talented writer/director.

This sums up Season One of Top of the Lake: "Give up. There's no way out," GJ. Foul language, nudity, sex, rape, incest, pedophilia, illegal drugs, and child/animal abuse. This series has no redeeming graces. There are holes big enough in the screenplay that semis could drive through them. Holly Hunter (GJ)  is not a great actress, but she really took a dive in this series and she still needs speech therapy. Don't waste your time. Turn off the TV and hug your kids.

If only there was a book I could read so I could find out what was going on!
The 'plot' is sketchy at best with huge gaps that never get filled; why does the evil patriarch self-flagellate, why does he feel he "owns" paradise, who is the baby's father, why does Tui's mother not have any role in searching for her or taking care of her later, how does this dumb cop survive when she constantly puts herself in thoroughly dangerous situations, who killed the teenager on the road, what the hell was going on in any of the myriad subplots?  Episode one and most of two pulled me in and I stuck it out to the end, when I became angry and disappointed. I honestly couldn't care less about any of the characters by the end. Any empathy for the 'heroine' was erased by her truly unbelievable stupidity. The overall impression is one of potentially intriguing characters and plot lines neither of which ever get developed leaving everything to the imagination. While this may have been the point, I did not find it enjoyable. Too much camera time spent on brooding expressions and very little useful dialogue. Some interesting sex scenes, some predictable deaths. Everyone in the town is sick, twisted, and more or less evil. Useless!!!

Worth watching only for the scenery, otherwise depressing and incomprehensible at most points, filled with vile characters, all of whom cannot speak a single sentence without including profanity. Poor New Zealand deserves better!
Dark and depressing - a bit "all over the place." Not overly enthusiastic about this movie - perhaps I think it given more positive production than it deserves.
Not what I was expecting.  It's okay.  Leaves you hanging.

Could only bring myself to watch two episodes of this series.  Perhaps it appeals to those wishing to see the dark side of mankind but having lived in New Zealand, it certainly didn't appeal to me!  Paints a very dark picture of the inhabitants of one small town.  Most Kiwis are full of joy and "connection".  I found neither quality in any character in "Top of the Lake"!  (and Holly Hunter was weird beyond words)
happy with purchase
What a series to watch---we thoroughly enjoyed this mini series,  wish it had continued!

Nitty gritty reality of small town New Zealamd, where a lot of the rough locals work for a meth lab owner from Scotland.  The women are single mothers who wanted to escape the low pay and cramped living of Christchurch.  They do not want the upstart young police detective intervening with their livelihood or personal lives.

Local men are shown as very wild, always drinking, taking drugs or out fishing and hunting, always armed, violent, driving offroad vehicles and getting Maori tattoos.  At least, most of them seem to be very lowdown and of low income.

Our main protagonist or heroine is pulling just one thread out of this wool ball by investigating the suicidal pregnant 12yearold Tui.  Rescued from the big lake and questioned, the girl is then released to the wild Scottish father, then she disappears.  The chase or rather, police hunt, begins.

With lots of red herrings and side paths such as the detective's dying mother and her reluctance to marry her fiance, while an old high school boyfriend gets her straight into intense sex after 15 years away from each other, well as a viewer you may well complain that you cannot quite follow all the loose and extraneous ends.

I will not reveal all the plot twists and turns.  Suffice to say that the film
may really annoy a lot of people.  It is too darn slow and meandering for our modern sensibilities.  I confess I started writing Christmas cards with only one eye on the film because the kiwi landscape was not eye candy for me.  I live in Northern California;it looked familiar.

The scumminess of the local people in their dress, haircuts, foul language and amoral behavior can leave a viewer with a bad dirty feeling about life in general.  Their violence and drugs and drinking show the New Zealandrts as a desperately spiritually lost people. Of course these are the criminals and the USA is full of similar types incliding thr hippie women at the Paradise ranch living in containers.  So no offense!

I found the final denouement pretty disgusting and a surprise too.  That house of the police inspector looks just like Sausalito here near San Francisco.

But why was Tui a different race than her father and brothers?  Never clear.  She looked straight from Vietnam and I couldn't figure that out.  Adopted?  Did I miss something?

Was Mitchum lying about everything?  The movie ends with a lot of loose ends.

Nonetheless for the patient or for those who have some ironing to do or maybe knitting could get through this long series.

The women in this film let men do things to them.  They make themselves victims.  That is one reason the children suffer too.  Men cannot be controlled sexually. That is the clear message.  Never trust any of them.
Good
very different type of series
Just okay strange
somewhat spooky at times and  disjointed but I enjoyed trying to keep track
Terrible - I threw it away!

Don't miss this one.  It's got a drop of Twin Peaks in it, a performance by the amazing Elizabeth Moss, and the incredible grandeur of New Zealand.  A fantastic ensemble of actors and great story rounds it out.  I couldn't figure out whodunit, and the ending came as a big surprise.  Very entertaining and involving, but so dense you could write an essay on it.  Top of the Lake is top notch.

I'm astonished this has been applauded by critics all over the place.  As a fellow Australian, I appreciate Jane Campion's catalogue of work, but feel that in this one, she definitely let the side down.  The New Zealand scenery is impressive.  But the plot lurches through yet another story of a vulnerable lady policewoman returning to the place of her roots to investigate a crime that brings back unwelcome memories of her past.  How many times have we sat through that?  Boring.  And Holly Hunter must have been hard up for a free holiday - or a job!  Otherwise why would she accept a (mercifully for the viewer) smallish part as a sort of airy-fairy guru presiding over a community of 'lost' women who apparently live in shipping containers?  Yes, it gets that ludicrous.  And I repeat, Holly Hunter's character comes over as ridiculous, particularly at the end where she heads off into a barren hinterland, dragging her luggage.  Where is she heading?  An airport?  The distant horizon?  I was just glad to see the back of her.

The 'mystery' isn't even that mysterious, or its solution any sort of surprise.  Elisabeth Moss does her usual good job, as do several other supporting players, but frankly there are better, more stimulating ways of passing - instead of wasting -  one's time.
this was totally unexpected, and really pleasant surprise.  loved the new zeland scenery.  really recommend it

This is a great series.  It is amazing that these attitudes still exist is this day and age.  We know it exists in third world countries but New Zealand and Australia are not my idea of third world countries.  It is educational, enlightening, angering and definitely a hot topic for conversation.

I know I am in the minority, but I wasn't all that thrilled by this show.  It was very easy to figure out who the "bad guy" was and some other major plot points could be seen coming a mile away.  Elisabeth Moss and some of the other actors did a great job, but at least one actor mumbled his way through the whole thing so badly that I could barely understand a word he said.
I enjoyed this dark drama. I loved the fact that this was New Zealand

This show is dreadful. It's full of unattractive actors and actresses, most of them downright ugly. Even the main character is a plain Jane. There's a commune of what El Rushbo calls femi-nazis, led by a supposedly mystical woman with long gray nasty looking hair, played by Holly Hunter. One of her flock is a nymphomanic who weighs about a deuce and a half and goes into town to the local bar, full of nasty looking losers, and slaps money on the bar for the first one to pick it up to come give her a good fuc king in 7 minutes.
The bad guy is a Robert Plant lookalike, with two Aryan brotherhood looking thugs for sons, and a 12 y/o daughter who is pregnant, which is the big mystery - who knocked her up.
There's also the obligatory puke scene, where the mother of the pregnant girl pukes when she gets the bad news. Why is it that every other show has to show someone puking? This show made me want to puke.
only wish there was some added footage/behind the scenes/making of/ actor -director comments, but i am obsessed w/ this show. would have love to seen (awesome) location scouting.
great film
Builds to new heights of depravity and depression...
What a great series, that had you going the entire time.  You really never knew who, "did it" until the very end.  I wish we could see a second season, but I understand why their is not.

When I first ordered this BBC series, I had some trepidation due to the product description.  It sounded a lot like BROADCHURCH, which I had just watched and enjoyed.  Luckily, it turned out that TOP OF THE LAKE was a lot more mysterious and moody in its presentation - something I happen to particularly enjoy.  Straight-out cop dramas don't hold a lot of interest for me, just to give readers an idea where this reviewer is coming from.  So I was particularly intrigued with the character played by Holly Hunt - an enlightened but somewhat gruff "guru" who was being followed by a group of "damaged" women who had come to the little town of "Paradise" in an attempt to heal mind, body and spirit.  I found this segment of TOTL to be the most interesting, so I was a bit disappointed that it seemed to garner the least amount of screen time.  But that aside, Holly Hunter & the other band of misfit women brought a real spark of philosophy to the show that raised it a notch above most of its "competitors."

The plot kept the viewer guessing from moment to moment - the crazy "hillbilly" father, his two drug-dealing sons, the missing girl's gay friend - the cast of characters was diverse and refreshingly unique.  Something the BBC can excel at.  I actually found the lead investigator to be the least interesting character of all.  Despite the sympathy which was built for her, and the ways in which she mirrored the missing girl's life history, I just found the character to be flat - but luckily the story held together in spite of that minor flaw.

To avoid spoilers, I'll simply say that the story is intense, gripping and well-plotted and well-paced.  The music was exemplary - adding an element of mystery and sad overtones, similar to the unforgettable score from the old US series, TWIN PEAKS.  In fact, I found TOP OF THE LAKE to be similar in mood to Twin Peaks throughout - so if you are a fan of TP, I'm pretty sure you will find TOTL right up your alley.

Performances throughout were excellent, and my only regret is that the series seems to have come to a final conclusion - all the loose ends tied up nicely, so it doesn't look like there will be a second season unless it takes off on a completely different storyline with different characters.  Overall, Top of the Lake is moody, mysterious and haunting long after the end credits have rolled.

I had heard that this was a good series but oh..my. Talk about some very different characters.
I hope this one continues. Lots to talk about with your friends because some of the actions
depend on how you interpret things..that is what really happened in some scenes. This is a
must see. Some great acting and what a plot.

A bit of a slog at times -- pacing is purposely slow -- and New Zealand accents can be challenging (No wonder Elizabeth Moss needed a dialect coach, just to play a transplanted Aussie.) But all performances are solid, especially Moss and Holly Hunter, and the don't-see-it-coming finale is worth the wait.

Its...Different. I liked most of it.  The women portrayed in it... to this women..that would be me... seemed over the top.. and yet like real women that I have met in my life time.. Acting good to fantastic. Story gritty... not for the lite and superficial taste. I would not say.. don't bother. it has merit. Holly Hunter's character was understated and yet.. "out there"... Im having a difficult time writing this... I don't know if I would recommend it. Why I would recommend it.. but I liked it.

I bought this DVD because I like the lead actress, Elizabeth Moss, and because I thought this might be a worthwhile detective story. I found Elizabeth Moss very sympathetic, but the story was too depressing and not worth the intrigue. I would have liked a fuller explanation of the motives of the "bad guys".
Great acting, good cast assemble, fantastic scenic views and the camera work was amazing. I can see this tale unfolding in Canada, Alaska, Hawaii, Oregon or Washington state....
Too many people in this movie who are mentally/emotionally damaged. I couldn't finish all of the episodes - too depressing for me.

Elizabeth moss is awesome who knew president bartletts daughter was up to this stuff-a lot of colorful characters who litter this tale ,so be ready to binge watch this and be sad when its over-I consider myself pretty hard to surprise but I was caught off guard by the twist and rewatched to see if I should have seen it coming but really it was such a complex mnage that many things could have been forshadowed,my good friend said why not just catch it for free on sundance but this quality stuff needs to be supported if we want more,holly hunter is excellent as usual  tls

this show was amazing. loved every second of it, although it certainly is brutal, it is a quality show. Jane Campion is SUCH a amazing director...but i gotta give it up to her writing abilities here...that script was insane, aggresive, sad, glorious and meserizing...Top of the Lake won't be for everybody. Its highly likely to offend....that said, as a adult, i couldn't believe how amazing this show was.

the finale was seriously jump out of my bed riveting. HUGE surprise ending.

totally recommend.

Maybe my eyeballs were crossed, but watching a very-very painfully dragged out story about a female detective that gets so played by so many vile characters ~ continually, or a girl gang raped at 16yrs. whos Catholic mother forces her to bring the baby to term, or a story about a 12yr. old girl who doesnt know how she got pregnant and runs away, or about a town, city, area where women set up a community in Paradise, which is like starting a community in hell is NOT my idea of an award winning mini series and in my opinion, the ending falls like a wrecking ball.

If one enjoys vile stories filled with vile characters in a god-forsaken area of earth one may enjoy this.

I expected that this mini series would have the usual strangeness associated with the work of it's director/co-writer Jane Campion and I was not disappointed. The real star was New Zealand! So very beautiful and mysterious.

Robin Griffin is a policewoman who returned to her home town as her Mother is gravely ill with Cancer. While there she is asked to aid the local police with a case involving a pregnant teenager. The young teen disappears and the search for her begins a process for Robin (Elizabeth Moss) to uncover her own past with the town and the under lying culture of it's inhabitants. These folks are down right strange....and mysterious like the mountains and waters that surround them.

Some of the performances are great but others are lacking....as is the plot writing. All in all the series was good but could have used another episode or two but then again...I was glad it was finally over! Yes, strange.

I was gravely disappointed in this DVD.  It was too dark in both lighting and content. Would not recommend unless one wants to become depressed. Sorry! I read that the scenery was excellent of New Zealand-not so in my opinion. It did nothing to make my want to visit there.
The movie was slow moving, and the story line was not very clear. The acting was good, but I fast forward a lot of it, due to how slow it went.
So eerie, creative and original. I loved it and wish more filmwriters would make series as a new art form. Ee

Very enjoyable, kept you going all the way.  The end was like "holy cow".

To me a great story transfers an experience and takes you for a ride and that's what they did with this.

Also this was a story that's multifaceted and kept you moving with it but never left you hanging

There's plenty of reviews with the particulars of the story so I won't go over them again.  However, although it was really well done, I felt there were far too many distractions from the main plot.  Not to giveaway any spoilers here but with better editing this could have been riveting. With so many different avenues the story went down it diluted the strength of the story.  Too bad.  Great acting though.  Elizabeth Moss deserved her award, and her boyfriend, who was great as well was the guy in last years "The Bridge".

Elizabeth Moss plays Miss Marples on a special trip to New Zealand. I found the story fairly good but a bit long. Suffice to say the plot twists are interesting and have a lot of surprises. Some tips:

-
-
-
-
Don't read if you don't want spoilers

1)  It's okay to have sex with your sibling, as long as he covers his body with a lifestory of tattoos that he'll unveil for the female audience every episode.

2) if someone is depicted as the most evil, heinous villain in the first episode, wait for someone else to get that reveal later.

3) If you're gay in this town, spend less time dyeing your hair blonde, and more time on mountain climbing lessons.

4) If you give Elizabeth Moss a gun with a full load of bullets, plan your teen roofie party for *after* she leaves town. Duh.

5) If you're a female resident of Laketop, you can turn a blind eye to decades of teen abuse, while Elizabeth Moss fills all the men with bullet holes.

Enjoy your stay in Middle Earth!

A very rambling movie, full of nudity, cussing, and nonsense that takes away from the plot of the story.  The story plot is moving and can hold you, but the side issues are a failure and boring.  This movie was not good, simply put.

this is so boring that I can sleep through it not knough the difference
lowest of the low bad terrible

We enjoyed this so much which is why we bought the DVD. Elizabeth Moss was exceptional and the story was excellent. Holly Hunter's participation was a waste of her talent. On the whole however, a great story.
The only thing I have to say for this film is it's  not worth the money to buy it you will be disappointed.

It took me a while to get into this series....but I persisted, because everyone I know who saw it raved about it along with many critics I admire. Once again, Jane Campion has brought us to New Zealand where a young girl has disappeared from her "family home". Elizabeth Moss is brought on the job, and plopped in the midst of a rather suspect police department, a town full of quirky and creepy citizens and a past that won't let go of her.

I loved the cast....who were not only well chosen but displayed superb acting skills-especially David Wenham and Robyn Nevin. Some of the dialogue was hard to hear- mumbling etc and too softly spoken to catch what was being said. Still the plot, which twists and turns- mostly on the tortured Moss, moved along at a good pace. I wasn't sure why Holly Hunter was in this piece, and some of the scenes with the women's "village" seemed pointless to me.

There is a lot to ponder in this series, and I kind of hope that there is another one. So much to explore about our fragile human psyche and condition. I didn't love it, but I liked it a lot, and appreciated the clever plots and good cast.
I enjoyed this series because it always provided a twist in the story line which was unexpected.  Scenery was a definite plus.
Superb acting, great direction, incredible scenery, unexpected plot twists, interesting character development, and an engrossing story make this mini-series an entertainment bonanza.
no problem. It is a DVD. What can  say. I enjoyed it. a keeper. Wouldnt have ordered it if  didn't like it.

I didn't like this show as well as I liked "The Killing," but for those of you who liked "The Killing" this show is similar in many ways. It is a good drama and mystery, very well-acted, and it was entertaining.

I was about to write a review of Top of the Lake, but K. Harris has written it for me (and done a better job than I could have done). What I would add, however, is a heads-up to gentle viewers. There are some very disturbing scenes; I am thinking of one in particular which my husband and I both considered to be not only shocking but gratuitous. Overall, it is a dark mystery -- slowly evolving and disturbing on a number of levels (and meant to be disturbing and thought-provoking).  Its not simply violence that is shown (though there's plenty of that) but a deep, poisonous inhumanity that pervades the action. It reminds me of a troubling dream sequence when the shadow of the unease that the dream inspired carries over into the next day.  There are no clear boundaries here -- it's not a simple hero versus villain scenario.  Everything is blurred and somewhat distorted as our protagonist detective (played so well by Elizabeth Moss) wanders through this strange sequence of events. If you're a fan of Miss Marple of Miss Fisher mysteries, i doubt you'll enjoy it.  If Wallender is more your cup of tea, then I do recommend this series.

I was a bit apprehensive when I ordered this show but the comments convinced me to try it and am I ever glad I did. The acting was superb and the plot line kept my interest throughout the entire series. Watched it in a couple of nights and couldn't wait to find out the ending. I would recommend this to anyone that likes an interesting mystery that also makes you think. Glad I took a chance on it.

The crime involving a young girl is actually secondary in this story, as it is clear there are really no other suspects than Matt Mitcham, Who is the chief bad guy, a drug dealing, gang leader.  There is no doubt that Matt is guilty of something.  The main feature for me is the  wonderfully shot by Jane Campion,modern day New Zealand landscape with its dark, overcast rural / urban setting and the relationships between the characters (to give more away would spoil it for viewers)

What I really enjoyed were the performances by the leading actors : Elizabeth Moss (Detective : Robin Griffin), David Weham (Detective : Al Parker) and Peter Mullan (gang leader Matt Micham).  Elizabeth plays a young detective chosen to investigate a crime involving a young girl.

This two disc set of all seven episodes of this instant classic is well worth the price of admission. Often compared to True Detective or Breaking Bad, this is a subtle story set in a creepy New Zealand town that looks like it is set on another planet. The strange characters and the towns lawmen are right out of a Stephen King novel, and Katherine Moss (from Mad Men) is perfect as the female detective who specializes in child abuse cases and returns to her home town to confront her own childhood demons. this is a masterpiece, and I have never used that word to describe a TV show.
This is an unusual story of incredible pathology, I found it quite intriguing.  The backdrop of New Zealand was pulchritudinous.

I've wayched this series 6 times already. It leaves an air of mystery still, though not a frustrating one. Each time, I'm left with a new question and new answers. The acting is flawless. Elizabeth Moss' accent isn't perfect, but it's not distracting either (which accents usually are when not perfect) The scenery is breathtaking! This is the best miniseries in years, if not ever!

A really intelligent character driven mystery. Apparently some didn't delight in the many interesting subplots here. Elizabeth Moss really is amazing as are some of the supporting cast. Often you'll have the main character followed around by 2D filler-there were some really interesting characters and plot arcs here and I'm one of the many hoping for some type of sequel.

Every Jane Campion film or television project is worth seeing because of her intelligence, her political commitments, and her remarkable visuals; every one of them also has major flaws compounded by Campion's heavy-handedness with her messages. This recent miniseries produced, co-written, and co-directed by Campion is no exception to either rule: set in her native New Zealand, it involves a stunningly dramatic and mysterious setting, a mystery centered upon an atrocity committed to a beautiful girl, a determined detective trying to root out the truth, and a community around the victim that is involved in far more horrors than the detective ever dreamed. The parallels to the Danish TV show FORBRYDELSEN (THE KILLING) and to TWIN PEAKS (which also inspired the Danish series) are inescapable, especially given in how both those earlier shows matters of gender and violence stood front and center. Campion, of course, is one of the most intriguing feminist film directors in the world, are her analysis of violence committed against women is even more front and center than in its predecessors. In this miniseries, a 12 year-old girl, Tui (Jacqueline Joe), is found trying to walk into a great lake on New Zealand's South Island, and when she is rescued, it is discovered she is pregnant, but she refuses to name the father to a detective (Elisabeth Moss); soon after, she disappears entirely. As the detective becomes obsessed with finding this young girl, she runs up against an odd mixture of the lake's inhabitants: the girl's father (Peter Mullan), a violent and self-pitying local criminal patriarch; his son, the detective's former boyfriend, who comes to care for her; and an odd New Age community of women led by an androgynous, taciturn guru (Holly Hunter).

Campion's trademark gorgeous visuals and dreamy pacing kept me through the entire miniseries, and its really something to see, with the alien landscape of New Zealand's stark Lake Wakitupu and its nearby dramatic neighbor Mount Earnshaw. Some of the most remarkable shots are of helicopters, showing the landscape dwarfing the insectlike people crawling on it, or reducing the colorful stacked railroad cars of the New Age community to the scale of mere children's blocks. Whether the miniseries works as an actual narrative, however, is another matter. The mystery itself isn't very interesting and is fairly guessable, as is the big twist in the final episodes; there's also too much revenge fantasy, with nearly every rapist (the miniseries is fairly crawling with them) implausibly shot or maimed by story's end. Of the major actors, Moss and Mullan do the best work. As the detective Robin, Moss is very different here from anything we've seen her do before, and her quiet ability to assume command is nicely done. Mullan is ideally cast as a terrifyingly mercurial man who wallows in self-pit and who can be surprisingly tender before erupting into cruelty: one of the best (and scariest) bits in the show is a long sequence involving Mullan's tryst with one of the women (Robyn Malcolm, in a warm and fine turn) from the compound. Although Holly Hunter does excellent work as the guru GJ, and can strikingly evoke her character's air of electric quietude, she's burdened a bit by her own movie star aura (a less well-known actress would probably have suited the part more effectively). Jacqueline Joe has an unearthly beauty as Tui, but perhaps no child actor could have pulled the part off convincingly: the mirror of GJ at a different age (willowy, prophetic, and surprisingly tough), Tui has so much symbolic weight freighted onto her by Robin and the film alike that she struggles under the burden of it.

Top of the Lake was so good to start off, then so disappointing with the character of GJ.  It started off as this moody, well-written, and suspenseful mystery and then it shifted to this weak, depressive version of a Wes Anderson storyline.  Shame, it could have been great without that unnecessary dose of weirdness.  Really, really, really disppointing.
Didn't care for this at all.  Sorry I wasted my time on it.  Not sure what the fuss was about.

This series could have been very good.  Most of the characters were interesting, the setting was gorgeous, the general idea for the plot was decent.  All of the ingredients were there.  However.....  This should have been a 2 hour movie.  In stretching it out so much longer than that, the creators added so much that was unnecessary.  Unnecessary scenes.  Unnecessary characters.  And for the entire middle stretch of the series, nothing of substance actually happens.  In essence you could watch only the first episode and the last episode, and not miss much of importance.

An example.  The gathering of women at "Paradise" adds absolutely nothing to the story.  If that entire aspect were cut, not a darned thing would change.

The main character, the detective played by Elisabeth Moss (who did a good job), spends most of the series fumbling around without learning anything of use.  It is almost maddening how little of substance actually occurs during all of those investigative hours.  And when we finally, finally discover who the bad guy is, we realize that not one single thing that happened in all of those hours actually led to the discovery.  The discovery occurs simply by happenstance.  There is nothing logical or developed about it.  It is tacked on to the ending, leaving the viewer very unsatisfied.

Elizabeth Moss is excellent! I've never seen her before (no cable), and she is *perfect* in this.

Some pretty creepy trashy characters.
Holly Hunter's character is too over-the-top, bordering on corny. Nope, it passes corny and I blame the writers. That character could have worked if they'd been a little more subtle about it, but they tried too hard and it just makes me roll my eyes whenever she spoke.

The scenery is spectacular, and  yet I wouldn't want to live there.

Overall, it's depressing people-wise and in atmosphere.

My guess is that this series is trying to imitate the dark wonderful quirkiness of Twin Peaks. *braaaaap!* fail.

I watched this start to finish NONSTOP.

I wasn't expecting a miniseries to be one of the most original works of cinematic art I'd seen, but it was.

There is nothing cliche about this amazing film.

That's what it is - one very long film chopped into 7 parts for TV but one sweeping dramatic arc nonetheless.

It's like nothing else out there in the ways that count. Because watching it changes you, and that is the mark of all great art. If it doesn't change you it's just entertainment. It's not the story, or the character, or the situation...it's the WAY they are all revealed, which in turn reveals the director's eye and intent, which is what changes us when we watch it. Deeper things are said that cannot be explicitly stated as in any true work of art. Images reverberate and everything is skillfully, masterfully executed.
Don't miss this 7 part mini-series if you can help it.  When viewing, put the English subtitles on at once.  The final episode is a zinger.  Elizabeth Moss of Mad Men is wonderful as is Peter Mullan.

Beautiful scenery but that's about all the positive I can say about Top Of The Lake.  The only reason I watched all episodes is to see who the father of Tui's baby was. Not a very beliveable plot.  Having said all this, at least I didn't have to pay.  It's free on Netflix.

I will be blown away if no awards are given out to this great mini-series!  Not at all what I expected!  Very powerful, enjoyable performances from every cast member!!  I hope they make a follow-up to this series.

Watched it for free on another venue. It is so beautifully breathtaking. It is filmed in New Zealand.
Intelligent, action without gratuitous violence. It is about strong people. Individuals figuring out their complicated lives. The characters are 3 dimensional. Bad things happen in this beautiful, stunning place.
It was an unexpected surprise. I loved it.

This TV show is so underrated it's like a hidden jewel waiting to be found amidst the overrated, glorified TV shows and movies that everyone watches these days. The storyline is very well-written, captivating, and interesting all at once. Beauty and tragedy are effectively played side by side together with the shocking crimes, emotional+physical pain, and the beautiful backdrop of the New Zealand landscapes.

And I'm not talking Jane Campion, the writer and co-director, and the creator of The Piano, for which Holly Hunter won the Oscar. Holly is back in a far different guise here, but a fascinating character, as are so many in this seven-part, strange mystery. Campion tends to deal with sexual issues with an iconoclastic view. Things are a little more normal here, but still outre.

But the Jane I'm talking about is Jane Tennison, the riveting detective in Britain's Prime Suspect series. I think the Elisabeth Moss detective could eventually be trotted out again in another case. That might not be a good idea, as that might threaten the relationship that develops in this series, a gorgeous romance. But for my money, the character is one of the first interesting female detectives in a long time. Apparently, no one seems to know how to do them like those from the British empire.

Interestingly, Moss is an American; I can't tell if she has any ties to New Zealand. Yet she seems to have a flawless accent, or, that is, she delivers her take on it flawlessly; her lines are not self conscious, they just flow from whatever this accent is that she has developed. It would be interesting to know how many of the other actors don't have natural New Zealand accents, or some history with them ... a quick trip to IMDB could solve that, of course, but these days, it seems you don't have to be British or Australian, or American, or even a native speaker of English, to work all over the globe. Moss, the secretary-turned-copywriter in Madmen with the improbable hairdo, really gets to let her hair down here. She has something of an interesting curriculum vitae if you view a profile but personalities aside she seems to be quite an actress.

I basically loved the series ... and did not find the stuff about the women finding solace on drug lord Matt's erstwhile land jarring. It was funny, but maybe some comic relief was needed. It also pretty much all hung together, some parts coming back on each other with beautiful irony. I think if you are a Prime Suspect/Law & Order fan, you'll like this one.

*** spoiler alert ***

Top of the Lake is a unique and captivating mini-series that offers great writing, acting and direction, and a fantastic setting.  At first glance a crime drama, it defies genre conventions, but the tip of the hat to the horror genre in the opening sequence and music is not to be ignored.

Make no mistake; Top of the Lake is about New Zealand.  Any local will tell you that New Zealand is Paradise; Top of the Lake tells us about the dark side of that paradise.  Yes, there is an Appalachian (for example) version of this story - but this is a distinctly New Zealand story.

Top of the Lake is a portrayal of New Zealand culture and its problems as few other films or series have done.  "Once Were Warriors" is a notable exception, and it is no coincidence that that film also deals with issues of misogyny, violence, rape, teen suicide, child abuse and child molestation.

There is a lot of feminism in Top of the Lake, but it is New Zealand culture that is indicted, and men and women are both guilty.  There are many victims in Top of the Lake, but there are few innocents.  Women seem to limit their sins to denying, defending and otherwise enabling the behavior of men, and the dark side of the culture in general, but Top of the Lake wants us to question whether they are any less guilty.  We probably see this most clearly in Campion's main character Robin Griffin, played by Elizabeth Moss.

There are many good reasons to like Robin, and to identify with her.  But the viewer suspects Al Parker (David Wenham) early on, and grows uncomfortable as Robin fails to follow up on some fairly clear warning signs, especially when she blacks out and wakes up in his bed and clothes, but fails to have a rape kit done, or a blood test, or to do anything more than give Al a light questioning.  She has suspicions, but she fails to follow through on them.  It begins to resemble the denial and willful blindness that is so much a part of the local culture, and a strong theme of the series.

Robin continues to get drunk in bars filled with overtly misogynist men, including one who actually raped her as a teenager.  She rekindles an old relationship with an old flame, Johnno (Thomas M. Wright) in a no-means-yes moment in a pub toilet.  This old flame had abandoned her at a high school dance just before she was raped by four drunk local men.  He comes clean about being there, but refuses to deny planning it with them ahead of time.  She continues seeing him.

When the local drug lord, Matt Mitchum (Peter Mullan), the most obvious villain of the series, reveals to her that he is her father, and that her lover is therefore her half-brother, we feel her horror as she realizes that many of the local demons are inside of her as well, and have been all along (Al has DNA testing done, and reports that Johnno is not Matt's son.  However he also reports that Tui's baby is Matt's, almost certainly a lie.  We never know for sure).

As ugly as this all might sound, I continue to have a lot of sympathy and patience for Robin, as do most viewers I think.  Credit this to the acting of Elizabeth Moss, but of course Campion knows that it is important that the audience care about even such a deeply flawed character.

Campion may have less patience for Robin than we do.  GJ, the reluctant "guru" of Paradise, played by Holly Hunter, is inspired by the late Indian philosopher U.G. Krishnamurti, a friend of Campion's.  GJ has no more patience for Robin than for any of the "crazy bitches" living at Paradise.  Robin is apparently the "crazy bitch" that broke the camel's back, sending GJ off to Reykjavik, about as far from New Zealand as a person can get.

TOTL has everything that a suspense thriller needs - great writing and acting, exotic locales, weird characters, tragic losses, love and awesome plot twists. The New Zealand hinterland is the setting for a search for a missing 12-year-old girl. Her dad, a longhaired brutal alpha-male woodsman living on a compound, is a natural suspect in the disappearance. A female detective, a former townie, comes to the lake to be with her dying mother. She is battling memories of a brutal attack from years ago, and throws herself into the chase for the missing girl, along with the town's lazy and incompetent police force. Meanwhile, a commune of psychologically wounded women sets up camp on land owned by the alpha male.  Throw in a former pedophile, assorted trashy barflies, and mysterious source of date rape drugs, and you have the makings of a complex and compelling show. Great performances by Elizabeth Moss (the returning detective), Peter Mullan as the compound chief and Holly Hunter as the leader of the women's commune.

I started watching 'Top of the Lake' because I am a fan of Elizabeth Moss. Her role in this film is terrific, in fact it s so good, she should be nominated for an Emmy. From the first confusing episode to the last, I was hooked! This is one of the better mini-series I have seen.

'Top of the Lake ' is a seven-hour miniseries from filmmaker Jane Campion. Elisabeth Moss is a troubled Sydney cop investigating the disappearance of a pregnant 12-year-old in her small New Zealand hometown. This is a crime series concerned with heartbreak.  Moss's detective Robin Griffin is investigating the disappearance of Tui. Her father is Matt Mitcham, played by Peter Mullan, a Scotsman introduced as a villain. He is a drug taker, maker and rounder and owns the town.

There's a lake where the mountains should be, and green, green grass. Everything is topsy-turvy: An unborn baby is called a "time bomb," a gentle elder-care companion puts his fist through a wall. And around the investigation is a group of scarred women camped out on land called Paradise. Holly Hunter's GJ, gives advice, sips soup and drops truth bombs.

This is a police procedural like no other. The only ethical investigator, it seems is Elizabeth Moss's character. All s not what it seems, and the finale will leave you surprised.

Highly Recommended. prisrob 05-27-13

It seems. for my money, that TV series have gotten so much better over the years. Better writing, acting, directing that have all been bolstered by better budgets. The proof is in the pudding here.

Here's the scoop. Robin Griffin (Kate Moss) is a New Zealander who moved to Australia, became a police detective, and has moved back to New Zealand. She's on a case where a 12 year old local, Tui, has disappeared. Is she dead? Is she hiding? Dad is a local heavyweight with fingers in the drug trade. Robin needs to solve the case as old ghosts and local corruption rear their heads.

This is a great mix of clever scripting and atmosphere. This particular area of New Zealand, and the season in which it is set, give it an almost otherworldly feeling. It's so remote and desolate that a foreboding cloud hangs over everything. Yet there is a certain beauty to it that is undeniable. The viewer is up in the clouds of some other planet. The situation is well realized and gets increasingly more scary as the characters develop and the histories between them begin to bloom. All the elements of the script are meted out evenhandedly and in subtle fashion. I felt as though I were watching things happen as opposed to being told they were happening. The music and sound design were also very good. They underscored the loneliness and remoteness of the place and the lives of those living there. And the plot is really good. You think it's all over and then there's that little something Robin sees that says it isn't.

Jane Campion has been at it for years. She wrote and co-directed this and, for my dollar, she's at the top of her game. The only aspect of this I didn't care for was the Holly Hunter character heading up the women's commune. As you learn something of her in the final episode I suppose it makes sense. I merely found here annoying. But, that being said, this is about as good a series as I've ever seen on TV.

Welcome to Top of the Lake.  On your right, we have a conspicuously beautiful New Zealand landscape, all foggy mountains, pine forests, misty lakes. Straight ahead is Paradise. Literally. On your left, however, nothing is as it seems.  Everyone harbors a secret, some inner darkness, some seed of madness or corruption or evil.  Even the most innocent are caught up in whatever malevolence permeates the freezing waters and the chill air at Top of the Lake.

This is David Lynch on steriods.  The story covers 9 of the 7 deadly sins, every major vice is present and accounted for, nobody is who you think they are and just when you think you have someone pegged, you don't.  The 7 episode mystery is as compelling a piece of television as I have ever encountered.  .

Edgy and disorienting, the plot centers around the pregnancy and disappearance of 12-year old Tui Michum.  Australian police detective Robin Griffin (played by "Mad Men's" Elisabeth Moss) returns to her hometown in New Zealand to spend time with her dying mother. A specialist in crimes against children, Griffin is asked to investigate the case by her friend and former mentor, the  the local top cop affably played by David Wenham. Holly Hunter plays a small but key role as a genuinely wise and down to earth guru to a bunch of women who end up at the Lake because they pretty much have no place else left to go.  The entire cast is excellent, particularly Jacquine Joe as Tui, and Peter Mullan as Tui's father, Mack, by turns charming, vicious, monsterous and frequently all too human.

Where is Tui and who fathered her baby? That's just the beginning.  The lake harbors many secrets and a couple of red herrings.  There is intense drama, romance, real sadness, madness, some humor and lots of good writing...and the curveballs keep coming at you.  During the last fifteen minutes of episode 7, it's all you can do not to duck. "Top of the Lake," a co-production of the Sundance Channel,BBC Two and UKTV in Australia and New Zealand was directed by Jane Campion (Oscar nominee for "The Piano" and is the first TV series ever to screen at the Sundance Film Festival. A lot of good television is coming out of Australia and New Zealand. This certainly is among the best

Well done.  Reminiscent of The Killing as far as the "atmosphere" created by the director, yet it stands on its own two feet. Holly Hunter & Elizabeth Moss are both excellent & delve deeply into their characters, although Hunter's role is quite small.  Kudos to her for taking on the role which is so different from anything I've ever seen her do.  Visually appealing, albeit dark, & edgy, as well as deeply emotional.  I watched all of the episodes in one day, if that tells you anything.  I couldn't stop watching!

This is a good show, especially because of the amazing photography of the spectacular  jagged mountains and lake scenery in which it takes place.

The main story is interesting but lacks suspense, mainly because of the subplot of the Paradise property and the troubled women camping on it. This subplot has nothing to do with the mystery and only distracts from it. The main purpose of this subplot seems to be to stretch the show to be a 7 part series, when in fact there is only enough material for about 4 parts.
In addition, there are many unnecessary details which don't add much to the character development and don't give any clues to the mystery either, and in fact only take away from the suspense.
So in short, it could have been much better with a good editor, who would have shortened the show and made it more focused on the mystery.

As crime drama and mystery, this series starts well, with an excellent cast of idiosyncratic and well-developing characters as well as a darker if beautiful portrayal of what has become a popularized Middle Earth.  Unfortunately the crime and mystery become somewhat derailed by Campion's decision to devote most of the latter half of the series to romantic and existential explorations which detract and distract from the series' initial identity and story-thread.  Plus the fundamental impediment to the evolving romance is summarily dismissed at the end by what can only be characterized as contrivance.

On the plus side, the acting is excellent, as is the cinematography, direction and production values.  Thus, even more unfortunate that Campion cannot successfully or fully integrate the disparate elements of the series' distinct storylines, but instead chooses to focus on crime and mystery at the start, then shift the focus towards an emerging relationship in the second half, at the expense of the former.  The result is what could have become a series on par with Bron/Broen, Forbrydelsen, The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, or Baran bo Odar's The Silence, but instead awkwardly becomes several stories clumsily separated and only marginally cobbled together at the end.  As for the "Paradise" setting/metaphor, it remains marginalized and enisled throughout.

2 and a half stars...

I just finished watched episode 5 and this is a series that will stay with me for a long time. The actors are all fantastic, the scenery amazing, and I wish there was more T.V. like this . Well done to all who contributed to this brilliant series.

NO SPOILERS:

I contemplated on how I could, sans spoilers, give a review on a 7-part mini-series as complex in nature as "Top of the Lake" (TOL).  I decided that I would comment on the imagery, performances and try to put in some perspective re: other programs.

First and foremost, kudos to Sundance.  There are an increasing number of good and unique programs coming from Australia/NZ that don't make it through conventional channels to the USA.  Apparently, Sundance co-funded with a sub of the BBC, who stepped in when ABC (Australian Broadcasting Company) pulled funding when an American actress (Elizabeth Moss) was cast in a lead role (I guess that it is OK for Aussie actors/actresses to work on USA produced programming, but not the inverse?)

The catch phrase for describing this series is the opening scene of a young girl (Tui - 1/2-Thai) peddling her bike from the family compound to a lake, wadding in, being noticed and pulled out when the monitor of a passing school bus recognizes her and as the school nurse is toweling her off, low and behold, a baby "bump".  While this might be a lot to process in its own right, there are so many layers of complexity that simply thinking that the story is about a pregnant 12-old girl that goes missing, does a disservice.

As the show progressed, the best (though far from perfect) analogy that I came up with, was that TOL has elements of the AMC (AKA USA) version of the program "The Killing" with perhaps of small element of "Twin Peaks" mixed in.

Moss does an admirable job putting her Kiwi on, as a Sidney Detective visiting her cancer ridden mom and being drawn into the case due her experience with children.  There is also some time given to Moss's back story while in HS at the TOL.

Holly Hunter gives a strange performance as some sort of sage that sets up a commune by the lake where woman with various "issues" all live in shipping containers.

Peter Mullan delivers the best performance of all as Matt Mitcham, Tui's father (from a prior marriage) and family patriarch.  I racked my brain searching for other performances by Peter Mullan and came back with 2-seasons of the BBC program "The Fixer" (Mickey).

The imagery alone of TOL will have you running to google to price out flights and accommodations.

Patience pays off, as by the final episode the laundry list of questions are answered.

While this might not be for everyone, it is so unique, disturbing and complex, that if you find yourself in the right frame of mind, highly recommended.

I love that you have the series avalible so that we may enjoy and watch anything we may have missed. My only problem is I loved the music in the series yet my wife and I have gone several routes trying to find out to whom were the singers, single guitarist playing throughout the movie(voice was beautiful) or single songs for that may be attainable on amazon.com Have any advice?
Why I can get the second part in region 1?

What an odd series. The story is rambling and you are left to guess how things go. There is lots of long staring between antagonists. It's difficult to know if there are any protagonists. Why Elizabeth Moss she isn't a convincing Australian?
Set in New Zealand, this crime series is full of surprises.

This series made no sense. We start off with a missing girl who is pregnant. But shes simply in hiding, not missing. The detective - played by Elizabeth Moss, is pulled into the investigation for no clear idea. Shes visiting her old hometown as her Mother is sick And somehow ends up running the investigation. Shes concerned the missing girls family, especially her father (played by Peter Mullen) are behind her disappearance Trying to find out who got her pregnant comes back to the girls odd family dynamic. Throw in Mosss characters boyfriend-who seems to be a drug addict working for the missing girls Dad-oh and by the way he may have given up his girlfriend years ago to a group of guys who raped her. Throw in Holly Hunter making an appearance as the leader of a group of dysfunctional women who camp out on land owned by the missing girls Dad. Except Hunter is given nothing to do but sit about and look mystical. Its a mess. Dont bother. I only gave it one star because I thought Moss was still good in the role
awesome and crazy

I enjoyed Top of the Lake - China Girl, recently on Sundance, so bought the first series. What a disappointment and a waste of 6 hours. If I had seen this one first, I probably wouldn't have watched the second one. Although I liked Elisabeth Moss' performance, the rest of the characters were the most miserable, horrible people that I've seen in a series. The entire storyline with Holly Hunter was a total waste of time. I wish I could get my money back.

One of the most vile movies I have ever seen. Continual, unrelenting use of strong profanity.  Every single character lack morals. A dog shot is dead right after being fed for no reason at all other than the man who shot him is a psychopath. This man is able to also kill people at will because the police are under his thumb. He has trained his sons to kill as well. A policeman gives information to him which results in another killing. His 12 year old daughter is pregnant and when he is told he brags that he had his first f*** at age 11 and says oh well if she's a slut, she's a slut. His grown son is sleeping with the mother of the 12 year old. This same son has a sexual encounter with the main female police character in the bathroom of a bar and then goes out to continue socializing with two other women. An older woman goes into a bar, lays money on the counter and says that it is for a seven minute sexual encounter (only she uses profanity). A man takes her up on it and follows her to a room where they have a bizarre encounter. I could go on and on and I didn't even watch half of this. I wanted to see what happened to the pitiable 12 year old child, but could wade through this cesspool no longer.

Excellent story, well acted and beautiful NZ scenery, what else could you want. I had a look at the first episode then had to see the second, before I knew it I had seen the first 4 episodes, and then had to watch the rest as time permitted. Very enjoyable story leading up to what never saw coming.

I checked this out from my library.  Where do I begin?  Way to many "F bombs" thrown around. I started laughing at some of these "F bombs" tantrums.  It's like watching children when people throw around the "F bomb" a lot.  This show had way to much misogyny in it. I couldn't take the lead detective Robin Griffin serious.  What a messed up character.  By the time I got to episode 6 I couldn't wait for it to be done. What can I say, I'm a completionist.  Wish I could shake that.
Great BBC series
